results.title: Looking at plants
results.creator_credit: Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School, Jim Harris and John Bird
results.brief_description: Filmed in the Sherbrooke Forest Park, Australflora Nursery, Victoria, and shows glimpses of the plant and insect life which abound there. No narration, music only.

results.title: Looking at paperwork
results.creator_credit: Rank Organisation Film Productions, British Productivity Council and Robert Parker
results.brief_description: Presents an Organisation and Methods approach to administrative practice, showing typical ways of improving its efficiency. Two questions are asked - “How is the work being done?” and “Is the work being done really necessary?”.

results.title: Looking at mammals
results.brief_description: Some of the 2,000 animals on the Hollywood film set of ‘Dr Doolittle’ illustrate the importance of animal classification. While showing the difference between birds, amphibians, reptiles and mammals, the film introduces Flower-Face, the trained hippo; a giraffe that can be ridden; a chimp that smiles on command; along with unusual reptiles and birds.

results.title: Looking at Leeuwin
results.creator_credit: Australia. Navy Office. Directorate of Public Relations
results.brief_description: Royal Australian Navy’s Junior Recruit Training establishment HMAS Leeuwin at Fremantle in Western Australia. Shows junior recruits at academic and practical classes, on board a Navy destroyer and at sport and play. Discusses further opportunities for junior recruits after their graduation.

results.title: Looking at gold and silver
results.creator_credit: Realist Films, Worshipful Company of Goldsmiths, J.B. Holmes and Adrian de Potier
results.brief_description: Surveys the goldsmiths’ and silversmiths’ art, bringing together an assortment of beautiful and ornate treasures from Rome, 7th century Ireland, India, mediaeval England, the work of famous goldsmiths such as Paul de lamerie, and ends with a brief look at contemporary craftsmanship. The objective of the film is to encourage people to look at fine craftsmanship with an educated eye.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Realist Films, Worshipful Company of Goldsmiths, J.B. Holmes and Adrian de Potier

results.title: Looking at children's movements (TEFC)
results.brief_description: The study of movement in human beings is beginning to be treated scientifically, and a study is being made of infants from birth. It seems likely that predictions can be made from the study of an infant’s movements about his or her attitudes and character throughout life. Contains b&w sequences.
results.description: The study of movement in human beings is beginning to be treated scientifically, and a study is being made of infants from birth. results.title: Looking at Britain: Young Farmers Clubs
results.creator_credit: Max Munden Productions and Maxwell Munden
results.brief_description: Farmers display cattle, sheep, produce at Kent County Federation of Young Farmers Clubs. Shows young farmers conducting their own school farm; visiting various farms, research stations and orchards.

results.title: Looking at Britain: trainers in training
results.creator_credit: Max Munden Productions and Maxwell Munden
results.brief_description: Training athletic coaches. To make sure there will always be enough expert instruction for the youth of Britain there are several colleges where future instructors are trained. One college is Loughborough. Here teachers of physical education are taught the techniques of different sports, learning not only to be good athletes themselves but how to pass their knowledge on to others.

results.title: Looking at Britain: British press
results.brief_description: Fleet Street is the home of three-quarters of England’s major newspapers, 16 million of which are printed every day. Shows how a newspaper gathers its news, the various functions of its staff, printing, despatch and distribution.

results.title: Looking at animals: the dog family
results.brief_description: Introduces the domestic dog as a pet, but also shows it to be a natural hunter. Includes close-ups of jaws and teeth and demonstrates speed of running and methods of swimming. Describes wild dogs of various types and shows working dogs in action.
